results.title: Bigfoot in Harry and the Hendersons
results.creator_credit: William Dear, Richard Vane and Universal Studios
results.brief_description: George Henderson (John Lithgow) is on the way home from a camping trip with his wife Nancy and children Sarah and Ernie, when he accidentally hits and kills what seems to be a wild animal. A closer inspection reveals what they all believe to be the mythical ‘Big Foot’. Visions of richness are revealed to George, and against his family’s wishes, takes the dead creature home with him. Later that night, strange noises wake the entire family, who go downstairs to find Harry, the Big Foot they killed, is actually alive. Their lives are turned upside down by Harry, who destroys their house, but gains their love. The Hendersons decide the best thing for Harry would be to return him to the wild, but before they can, he escapes. Hot on his trail are amateur hunters and professional ‘Big Foot’ hunter, Jaques Lefleur (David Suchet). The family, with the help of environmentalist, Dr Wallace Wrightwood (Don Ameche) race against time to return Harry to his home - before he ends up in a zoo.

results.title: Big Wednesday
results.creator_credit: John Milius, Buzz Feitshans and A-Team Productions
results.brief_description: Set between 1962 and 1974, “Big Wednesday” is the story of three surfing friends - Matt, Jack and Leroy. We see their loves, fights and the hero worship that follows them as they conquer the waves. The South Swell 1962: the three rule the waves. Together with their friends they get drunk, go on surfing holidays and have wild and destructive parties. As the years pass, the Vietnam War and growing up take their toll. They witness the changes in themselves, their home and friends. The Great Swell 1974: Matt, Jack and Leroy re-unite to brave one last journey together, to surf the great swell. “Big Wednesday” encapsulates the emotions of passing youth against the splendour of the sea and surfing. Includes a special appearance by surfing legend, “Mr. Pipeline”, Jerry Lopez. Cast includes: William Katt, Gary Busey, Jan Michael Vincent, Patti D’Arbanville and Lee Purcell.

results.title: Big brother of Christmas Island: Tai Ko Seng [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mathew Kelley, Peter Du Cane, Samantha Kelley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This documentary explores the significant role Gordon Bennett played in the development of the union movement on Christmas Island. Bennett immigrated from England to Australia and quickly rose in the union ranks. In 1979 he arrived at Christmas Island to help the workers union improve worker conditions. He was responsible for significant changes and during his twelve years became a folk hero to the local inhabitants.

results.title: Beyond the rift wall
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Gobeil, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Canadian International Development Agency
results.brief_description: A film about a group of farmers and their wives who went to live and work among the Tanzanians, training them in Canadian methods of grain growing and production. It examines the cultural effects of this exchange both on the Canadians, who found themselves isolated by geography and language, and on the Tanzanians who were exposed to Canadian work habits and technology.

results.title: Beyond kicks
results.creator_credit: Gary Toole, George Pearson, Michael McKennirey and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is about a group of young volunteers, the Free Youth Clinic, who run a ‘crisis bus’ to rescue young people experiencing bad drug trips, usually LSD. They pull up whenever the need arises and try to talk the person down. If the patient needs further medical aid, they know where to obtain it. The film shows some of the patients being interviewed after their rescue.

results.title: Beyond Everest (1980). Beyond Everest: the ongoing climb of Sherpa Hillary (2000)
results.creator_credit: Michael Dillon, Dick Smith Adventure and Michael Dillon Film Enterprises
results.brief_description: Conquering the mountain of Everest was not Sir Edmund Hillary’s only achievement in Nepal. Through a philanthropic enterprise he continued to fund development projects for the Nepalese people - projects that the people themselves requested. His legacy will live on through the children of Nepal attending one of the some 30 schools that his “Himalayan Trust” built since 1961 - in many cases by his own hands. This DVD contains two documentaries - one made in 1980 is about Sir Edmund at sixty years of age and the other made in 2000 continues the subject matter of his philanthropic work - the DVD release commemorates the 50th Anniversary of Sir Edmund Hillary’s ascent of Mount Everest.

results.title: Between two wars: sunshine and eclipse (1927-1934)
results.creator_credit: William Weintraub, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Confident, prosperous Canada, expanding in all directions; then the stock market crash of 1929, its sequel the Great Depression, and a nation staggering with poverty and unemployment. But with it all, an optimistic outlook: bargains by mail order; extremes in women’s fashions; political see-sawing; hockey broadcasts by a very youthful Foster Hewitt; the word “quintuplets” in every headline.

results.title: Beyond the clouds = Par-dela les nuages
results.creator_credit: Michelangelo Antonioni, Philippe Carcassonne, Stephen Tchal Gadjieff, Cecchi Gori Group, Cine B, France 3 Cinema, Road Movies Zweite Produktionen and Sunshine
results.brief_description: This was Antonioni’s return to filmmaking after suffering a stroke in 1985. He presents 4 vignettes linked thematically by notions of desire, as well as a fictional director in search of a story (portrayed by John Malkovich). In the first story two beautiful lovers, Silvano and Carmen (Kim Rossi Stuart and Ines Sastre) are unable to consummate their love because of his pursuit of perfection. In the second story John Malkovich’s character meets a woman (Sophie Marceau) who confesses to killing her father. The third story involves a man (Peter Weller) who must decide between his wife (Fanny Ardant) and his lover (Chiara Caselli). In the final story a man (Vincent Perez) becomes obsessed with a woman (Irene Jacob) who is “satisfied” with life and is about to enter a convent. Screen legends Jeanne Moreau and Marcello Mastroianni make a brief appearance and have an overall involvement to the story rather than being directly involved with any of the vignettes. In French, Italian and English with English subtitles. Co-directed by Wim Wenders.

results.title: Beyond the blue meanies: the animation of Paul Driessen
results.creator_credit: Paul Driessen and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: After working on the Beatles’ animated film “Yellow submarine” Paul Driessen immigrated to Canada and joined the National Film Board in 1972. The six films in this compilation showcase the whimsical and unique style of a renowned prize-winning animator. Contains: “Le Bleu perdu/The Lost blue” : Grey smog clouds the earth and a young boy dons a pair of wings to learn that there is a clear blue sky; “Air!”: Clean, fresh air is becoming scarce as plants, birds, fish and finally, people, come to the same “breathless” end; “Cat’s cradle”: A parable using the metaphor of the cat’s cradle shows that all our lives are interconnected; “An old box”: During Christmas a lonely homeless man finds a magical box that takes him on a fantastic spiritual journey; “The Same old story”: Life is stranger than fiction — a truism that comes alive in this deceptively simple film; “The End of the world in four seasons”: Eight stories unfold simultaneously on screen in this witty black comedy to the accompaniment of Vivaldi’s Four Seasons.

results.title: Beyond reasonable doubt: the Leith Rattan case
results.creator_credit: Tristram Miall, Murray Travis and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Leith Rattan was found guilty of murdering his wife Beverly in their Echuca home and sentenced to death by hanging in a Shepparton Court. However, the verdict took many people by surprise and the sentence was later commuted to 25 years in prison. Rattan had always staunchly maintained that the shooting was an accident, although the police investigation seemingly identified a motive and opportunity. There were four appeals to higher courts on the grounds of the prosecution’s evidence and the original judgment made, however they were all dismissed. Through dramatised re-enactment and a thorough explanation of the forensic evidence offered at the original trial, presenter Gordon Hawkins casts doubt over the veracity of the evidence presented by the prosecution and asks was Rattan’s guilt proven beyond reasonable doubt? He also makes the point that the trial process itself is fraught with inequities and can often affect the accused person’s chance of a fair trial.
